summary:
I have been working as a Principal Investigator in Oncologic Imaging and Head of Computational Clinical Imaging Group at Champalimaud Foundation for over seven years. Champalimaud Foundation is a world-class biomedical research institution in Portugal that aims to improve human health and well-being through scientific discovery and innovation. My mission is to develop and validate radiomic signatures that can improve the diagnosis, prognosis, and treatment of cancer patients using advanced medical imaging techniques.

In addition to my role at Champalimaud Foundation, I also serve as the Machine Learning Imaging Lead at the Royal Marsden Hospital, one of the largest and most comprehensive cancer centers in Europe, where I apply artificial intelligence and machine learning techniques to enhance the clinical utility and interpretation of imaging data. Furthermore, I am an Honorary Reader at The Institute of Cancer Research, a leading academic institution in the UK, where I collaborate with multidisciplinary teams of scientists and clinicians to advance the field of imaging biomarkers. I have over 25 years of experience in oncologic imaging, multiple publications, certifications, and honors in this domain, and I am skilled in radiomics, machine learning, AI, MRI, medical devices, and oncology.

projects.description: An innovative, cost-effective way to give access to Radiologists state-of-the-art post processing services, provided by experts on the field using clinicaly approved software tools
projects.title: Remote Post Processing Services

projects.description: This two-day neuroradiology course, inaugurated last October in Athens, is led by experienced clinical neuroradiologists and MRI physicists, and embraces the role of MRI in neuro-oncology. The material is exclusively centered on advanced MR application techniques and the teaching sessions are accompanied by interactive discussions with case material. Short lectures introduce you to the main advanced MR applications (MR spectroscopy, MR perfusion imaging, Diffusion Tensor Imaging, and functional MRI) for diagnostic purposes in neuro-oncology and lay the groundwork for clinically orientated lectures devoted to review the indications for advanced MRI and clarify the interpretation of the findings. Attendees can participate in hands-on sessions including acquisition and post-processing techniques in order to get familiar with the techniques or to remedy perceived weaknesses.
projects.title: Advanced MRI in Neuro-Oncology (AMRINO)

projects.description: A European funded project with the objectives to build the largest repository of multi parametric MRI and clinical data in patients with prostate cancer, and to harness these data to develop and validate AI algorithms to address several important clinical questions. The consortium is comprised of 20 partners mostly based in Europe. I’m the scientific coordinator of the project managing 7 AI development teams being responsible for the design and implementation of all AI activities of the consortium.

publications.description: Advanced MRI techniques including diffusion and perfusion weighted imaging, has the potential to provide early surrogate biomarkers to detect, characterize and assess treatment response of tumors. However, the widely accepted Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors (RECIST) are still considered as the gold standard for the evaluation of treatment response in solid tumors, even if according to recent studies RECIST seem to disregard the extent of necrosis, which is the target of all effective locoregional therapies. This is partly due to the fact that measurements of tumor size aren't the best criterion for assessing actual early response. On the other hand, more sophisticated techniques such as the Apparent Diffusion Coefficient (ADC) and perfusion parameters are usually processed manually and evaluated independently using commercial CAD software, not widely available. In this paper we present an open access extensible software platform providing both diffusion and perfusion analysis in a single, user friendly environment that allows the radiologist to easily and objectively evaluate tumor response to therapy.
publications.name: A software prototype for the assessment of tumor treatment response using diffusion and perfusion MR imaging
publications.publisher: Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC), 2012 Annual International Conference of the IEEE / IEEE

message.text:
Proud Father:) Well done Konstantina Papanikolaou
#familytime, #lifetimeachievements
Interesting workshop organized by the AI4HF project; happy to participate and share my opinion.

Great multi-stakeholder workshop in Lisbon today! 💼 This morning, we explored clinical, patient, and ethical considerations gathered within the AI4HF (EU project). Especially insightful was the interface discussion and AI Passport walk-through with our PhD student Joan Perramon. 💡

And now, diving into future perspectives of AI-driven tools for heart failure treatment. 💙 We're pondering: How do we transition from risk prediction to day-to-day health management support? And how can AI-driven healthcare tools promote equity, not exacerbate disparities? Join us on this journey!
 
Follow the project for the latest updates: https://www.ai4hf.com/ 

#AIinMedicine #HealthTech #EthicalAI #Cardiology 🌐

As long as AI models are exploiting opportunistic correlations found explicitly on the training data, they will be suffering from limited generalizability. More data may help but not solve the fundamental problem of AI predictive models, since there will always be in the future data that doesn't resemble the training set since everything is changing ("The only constant in life is change", Heraclitus 6th century BC). Two possible solutions there i) continuous monitoring or ii) causal models, in my opinion.

ingestedContentSummary.description: Physicians rely on algorithms for personalized medicine — but an analysis of schizophrenia trials shows that the tools fail to adapt to new data sets.
ingestedContentSummary.title: Medical AI falters when assessing patients it hasn’t seen

commentary.text: Χρονια πολλά, υγεία και πολλές επιτυχίες
"Και οχι μονο", θα προσεθετα στον τιτλο, συγχαρητηρια στο καναλι και στον προσκεκλημενο.
In this example the average performance of a model on external data is 0.722 but in the most recent time the model has 0.25 AUC !!!

External validation (or out of distribution) performance estimation is mandatory, but not enough! We need to add the temporal notion of validation. We need to shift from static validation schemes were the data have been acquired somewhere in time, with a temporal validation where someone is measuring the models performance over time. There are several reasons why a model may not perform as expected or as promised by the vendor (data drifts, target drifts, concept drifts are the most important).

As long as AI models are exploiting opportunistic correlations found explicitly on the training data, they will be suffering from limited generalizability. More data may help but not solve the fundamental problem of AI predictive models, since there will always be in the future data that doesn't resemble the training set since everything is changing ("The only constant in life is change", Heraclitus 6th century BC). Two possible solutions there i) continuous monitoring or ii) causal models, in my opinion.
